intro: Sisymbrium subbipinnatifidum, commonly known as the narrow-leaved broomrape, is a parasitic flowering plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many flowering plants with small, cross-shaped flowers. The plant has a slender, branched stem and produces small, yellow flowers that are often clustered at the tips of the branches. Its leaves are narrow and pinnately divided, giving it a delicate appearance. It is typically found in sandy or disturbed soils and is native to regions of Europe and Asia.
